articles.headline: More Forceful Fed Stands by Stimulus
articles.snippet: Officials said that they would consider an expansion of bond-buying if conditions warranted, and added that federal budget cuts were hurting the economy.
articles.abstract: Officials said that they would consider an expansion of bond-buying if conditions warranted, and added that federal budget cuts were hurting the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that its economic stimulus campaign would press forward at the same pace it has maintained since December, putting to rest for now any suggestion that it was leaning toward doing less.

articles.headline: A Camera Takes On the Phones
articles.snippet: The Canon N emphasizes features that a smartphone can’t match and can transmit new photos to your phone for immediate sending or posting online.
articles.abstract: The Canon N emphasizes features that a smartphone can’t match and can transmit new photos to your phone for immediate sending or posting online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Technologies come and go in waves. And lately, the waves are coming and going faster.

articles.headline: Mobile Ads Help Propel Earnings at Facebook
articles.snippet: Facebook reported that about 30 percent of its total advertising revenue came from mobile devices, a significant jump from the last quarter.
articles.abstract: Facebook reported that about 30 percent of its total advertising revenue came from mobile devices, a significant jump from the last quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This time last year, just before Facebook made its public debut, the social network did not show a single advertisement on its mobile applications. And over time, the cries from investors about its mobile strategy grew louder and louder.

articles.headline: Medicaid Access Increases Use of Care, Study Finds
articles.snippet: New results from an Oregon study found that Medicaid coverage reduced the rate of depression and made low-income adults more financially secure, if not healthier.
articles.abstract: New results from an Oregon study found that Medicaid coverage reduced the rate of depression and made low-income adults more financially secure, if not healthier.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Come January, millions of low-income adults will gain health insurance coverage through Medicaid in one of the farthest-reaching provisions of the Obama health care law. How will that change their finances, spending habits, use of available medical services and — most important — their health?

articles.headline: Cross-Country Solar Plane Expedition Set for Takeoff
articles.snippet: The Solar Impulse, a plane with the wingspan of a 747, is the creation of a Swiss team working on fuel-free flight.
articles.abstract: The Solar Impulse, a plane with the wingspan of a 747, is the creation of a Swiss team working on fuel-free flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — When Bertrand Piccard was growing up in Switzerland, heady discussions about the boundless potential for human endeavor were standard fare.

articles.headline: Banks Ease Capital Cost of Loans to Brokers
articles.snippet: An arbitration case shows the different choices financial firms make about where to house virtually identical assets and how those decisions can reduce costs.
articles.abstract: An arbitration case shows the different choices financial firms make about where to house virtually identical assets and how those decisions can reduce costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: To attract financial advisers, brokerage firms often offer them loans. They are loans with a difference, however.

articles.headline: Cellphone Thefts Grow, but the Industry Looks the Other Way
articles.snippet: Police officials say the cellphone and handset industry has not done enough with technology to solve the theft problem.
articles.abstract: Police officials say the cellphone and handset industry has not done enough with technology to solve the theft problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a teenage boy snatched the iPhone out of Rose Cha’s hand at a bus stop in the Bronx in March, she reported the theft to her carrier and to the police — just as she had done two other times when she was the victim of cellphone theft. Again, the police said they could not help her.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Malia Wollan

articles.headline: Some Retailers Rethink Role in Bangladesh
articles.snippet: The Walt Disney Company has ordered an end to production of branded merchandise in Bangladesh, and other retailers are considering similar moves.
articles.abstract: The Walt Disney Company has ordered an end to production of branded merchandise in Bangladesh, and other retailers are considering similar moves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since a building with garment factories collapsed in Bangladesh last week, killing more than 400 people, Western apparel companies with ties to the country have scrambled to address public concerns about working conditions there.

articles.headline: A Rate Cut in Europe, and a Hint of Limits
articles.snippet: The bank remains unwilling or unable to wield the more powerful weapons that many economists say are needed to jolt Europe out of recession.
articles.abstract: The bank remains unwilling or unable to wield the more powerful weapons that many economists say are needed to jolt Europe out of recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — The European Central Bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low on Thursday. But its president, Mario Draghi, indicated that his promise last year to do “whatever it takes” to save the euro had limits.

articles.headline: New Chief at Intel Aims to Expand Chip Making
articles.snippet: Brian Krzanich takes over a company dominant in PC chips but lagging in making chips for hot products like smartphones and tablet devices.
articles.abstract: Brian Krzanich takes over a company dominant in PC chips but lagging in making chips for hot products like smartphones and tablet devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brian M. Krzanich, who on Thursday was named Intel’s next chief executive, knows he faces a hefty challenge when he takes over the world’s biggest maker of semiconductors.

articles.headline: Politics and Vetting Leave Key U.S. Posts Long Unfilled
articles.snippet: A backlog of vacancies in top posts throughout the Obama administration, especially in the State Department, has slowed policy making in a capital already known for inaction.
articles.abstract: A backlog of vacancies in top posts throughout the Obama administration, especially in the State Department, has slowed policy making in a capital already known for inaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Kerry is practically home alone at the State Department, toiling without permanent assistant secretaries of state for the Middle East, Asia, Europe and Africa. At the Pentagon, a temporary personnel chief is managing furloughs for 800,000 civilian employees. There has not been a director of the Internal Revenue Service since last November, and it was only on Thursday that President Obama announced a nomination for commerce secretary after the job was open for nearly a year.
